3.1 Question 1


Attaching package: 'dplyr'
The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag
The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

We will first convert flights data set to tibble so it can be viewed in a better format, then, then we’ll print the data

flights_dat <- as_tibble(flights)
flights_dat
# A tibble: 336,776 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830            819
 2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850            830
 3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923            850

10  2013     1     1      558            600        -2      753            745

# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>

Now we can see the table looks much more organized!

4 Question 2

This is what I have come up with using the pipe |> and the functions available in the dplyr package.

dist_tbl <- flights |>
  filter(month == 1) |>
  group_by(carrier) |>
  summarise(
    mean_distance = mean(distance, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd_distance = sd(distance, na.rm = TRUE)
  ) |>
  arrange(mean_distance)

dist_tbl
# A tibble: 16 × 3
   carrier mean_distance sd_distance
   <chr>           <dbl>       <dbl>
 1 YV               229          0  
 2 9E               476.       334. 
 3 EV               522.       294. 
 4 US               536.       553. 
 5 MQ               566.       223. 
 6 FL               691.       142. 
 7 OO               733         NA  
 8 WN               942.       496. 
 9 B6              1062.       681. 
10 DL              1220.       644. 
11 AA              1350.       626. 
12 UA              1462.       778. 
13 F9              1620          0  
14 AS              2402          0  
15 VX              2495.        98.2
16 HA              4983          0

5 Question 3

I realized that the carrier “OO” is the only row with “NA” sd_distance value, while “YV”, “F9”, “AS” and”HA” have a value of 0 for sd_distance. I will first use the filter() function to specify carriers that have a zero standard deviation distance.

# A tibble: 46 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time

#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>

We can see that each carrier has the same distance in each row, therefore when we calculate the squared sum differences between the distances and it’s mean, it will give us zero. Now I will see what the distances for OO carrier looks like.

flights_dat |> filter(carrier == "OO" & month == 1)
# A tibble: 1 × 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
1  2013     1    30     1222           1115        67     1402           1215
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>

We notice here there is only one row or observation so we cannot compute the standard deviation with just one observation, so it makes sense that the output we get when we attempt to calculate it is given as “NA” .

6 Question 4

I will approach this question by first grouping and summarise(), then I will use pivot_wider() to make sure that carriers are on the columns and months are on the rows.

long_dat <- flights_dat |> group_by(month, carrier) |> summarise(avg_delay = mean(dep_delay, na.rm = TRUE))
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'month'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.
long_dat |> pivot_wider(names_from = carrier, values_from = avg_delay)
# A tibble: 12 × 17
# Groups:   month [12]
   month  `9E`    AA     AS    B6    DL    EV    F9    FL    HA    MQ    OO
   <int> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
 1     1 16.9   6.93  7.35   9.49  3.85 24.2  10     1.97 54.4   6.49 67   
 2     2 16.5   8.28  0.722 13.8   5.54 21.5  29.8   5.18 17.4   8.09 NA   
 3     3 13.4   8.70  8.42  14.2   9.93 26.2  16.8  17.3   1.16  7.19 NA

7 Question 5

Checking the number of rows that were delayed but arrived on or before time then dividing it by the total number of observations to get the proportion

num_del <- flights_dat |> filter(dep_delay < 0 & arr_delay <= 0) |> nrow()
prop_del <- num_del / nrow(flights_dat) 
prop_del
[1] 0.437938

8 Question 6

Step 1:

step1 <- flights_dat |>
  group_by(origin, dest) |>
  summarise(unique_airlines = n_distinct(carrier)) |>
  filter(unique_airlines > 1)
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'origin'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.
step1
# A tibble: 128 × 3
# Groups:   origin [3]
   origin dest  unique_airlines
   <chr>  <chr>           <int>
 1 EWR    ATL                 4
 2 EWR    AUS                 2
 3 EWR    BDL                 2
 4 EWR    BNA                 2
 5 EWR    BOS                 3
 6 EWR    BWI                 2
 7 EWR    CHS                 2
 8 EWR    CLE                 2
 9 EWR    CLT                 3
10 EWR    CVG                 2
# ℹ 118 more rows

Step 2:

step2 <- flights_dat |>
  inner_join(step1, by = c("origin", "dest")) |>
  group_by(origin, dest, carrier) |>
  summarise(avg_arr_delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop") |>
  left_join(airlines, by = c("carrier" = "carrier"))
step2
# A tibble: 343 × 5
   origin dest  carrier avg_arr_delay name                    
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>           <dbl> <chr>                   
 1 EWR    ATL   9E              -6.25 Endeavor Air Inc.       
 2 EWR    ATL   DL              10.0  Delta Air Lines Inc.    
 3 EWR    ATL   EV              19.5  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 4 EWR    ATL   UA              10.5  United Air Lines Inc.   
 5 EWR    AUS   UA               4.28 United Air Lines Inc.   
 6 EWR    AUS   WN             -11.2  Southwest Airlines Co.  
 7 EWR    BDL   EV               6.78 ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 8 EWR    BDL   UA              22.6  United Air Lines Inc.   
 9 EWR    BNA   EV              17.7  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
10 EWR    BNA   WN              -2.13 Southwest Airlines Co.  
# ℹ 333 more rows

Step 3:

step3 <- step2 |>
  group_by(origin, dest) |>
  summarise(
    best_airline = carrier[which.min(avg_arr_delay)],
    worst_airline = carrier[which.max(avg_arr_delay)],
    min_delay = min(avg_arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    max_delay = max(avg_arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )
step3
# A tibble: 128 × 6
   origin dest  best_airline worst_airline min_delay max_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>        <chr>             <dbl>     <dbl>
 1 EWR    ATL   9E           EV               -6.25      19.5 
 2 EWR    AUS   WN           UA              -11.2        4.28
 3 EWR    BDL   EV           UA                6.78      22.6 
 4 EWR    BNA   WN           EV               -2.13      17.7 
 5 EWR    BOS   EV           B6               -4.01       6.87
 6 EWR    BWI   WN           EV                5.95      20.1 
 7 EWR    CHS   UA           EV              -14         16.2 
 8 EWR    CLE   EV           UA               -3.71       5.97
 9 EWR    CLT   US           EV                0.920     20.5 
10 EWR    CVG   9E           EV                1.40      21.2 
# ℹ 118 more rows

Step 4:

step4 <- step3 |>
  mutate(delay_diff = max_delay - min_delay) |>
  arrange(desc(delay_diff)) |>
  slice(1)
step4
# A tibble: 1 × 7
  origin dest  best_airline worst_airline min_delay max_delay delay_diff
  <chr>  <chr> <chr>        <chr>             <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>
1 JFK    ATL   9E           EV                 1.40       128       127.

Step 5:

Here we will see why the above has the greatest difference between the worst and best performing airlines

flights_dat |>
  filter(
    origin == step4$origin,
    dest == step4$dest
  ) |>
  group_by(carrier) |>
  summarise(
    num_flights = n(),
    avg_departure_delay = mean(dep_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_arrival_delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  left_join(airlines, by = c("carrier" = "carrier"))
# A tibble: 3 × 5
  carrier num_flights avg_departure_delay avg_arrival_delay name                
  <chr>         <int>               <dbl>             <dbl> <chr>               
1 9E               55                1.47              1.40 Endeavor Air Inc.   
2 DL             1874               10.7               6.34 Delta Air Lines Inc.
3 EV                1              124               128    ExpressJet Airlines…

Here we can see the huge differences among 9E and EV.

9 Question 7

First we load the data set

Now we check for missing values: “NA” in each row

quest7_data[rowSums(is.na(quest7_data)) > 0, ]
# A tibble: 5 × 15

# ℹ 6 more variables: smoker <chr>, exercise <chr>, income <int>,
#   education <chr>, region <chr>, marital_status <chr>

We can also check for unique entries using UtilsDataRSV

2  Practical Day 2
